@Composable

fun EventCard(singleEvent: SingleEvent) {

 Box(contentAlignment = Alignment.Center,
 modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 30.dp, start = 10.dp).clickable{}){
 Card(
 modifier = Modifier.size(width = 430.dp, height = 530.dp).padding(10.dp),
 elevation = CardDefaults.cardElevation(
 defaultElevation = 10.dp
 ),
 colors = CardDefaults.cardColors(
 containerColor = Color.White
 ),
 shape = CardDefaults.outlinedShape

 ){


 Box(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
 .height(300.dp)
 ){
 AsyncImage(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
 model = singleEvent.img,
 contentDescription = singleEvent.title,
 contentScale = ContentScale.Crop
 )
 Text(
 text = " "+ singleEvent.date,
 color = Color.White,
 fontSize = 16.sp,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
 modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.TopEnd)
 .padding(12.dp)
 .background(Color.Black.copy(alpha = 0.6f), shape = RoundedCornerShape(8.dp))
 )

 }
 Column {
 Text(
 text = singleEvent.title,
 modifier = Modifier.padding(10.dp),
 fontSize = 20.sp,

 color = Color.Black
 )
 Text(
 text = singleEvent.location,
 modifier = Modifier.padding(vertical = 5.dp, horizontal = 10.dp),
 fontSize = 16.sp,
 color = Color.Gray,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Normal
 )
 Text(
 text = singleEvent.time,
 modifier = Modifier.padding(vertical = 5.dp, horizontal = 10.dp),
 fontSize = 16.sp,
 color = Color.Gray,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Normal
 )
 Text(
 text = singleEvent.description,
 modifier = Modifier.padding(vertical = 5.dp, horizontal = 10.dp),
 fontSize = 14.sp,
 color = Color.DarkGray,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Normal
 )

 Row {
 Text(
 modifier = Modifier.clickable{}
 .padding(vertical = 5.dp, horizontal = 10.dp),
 text = "Learn More -->",
 fontSize = 16.sp,
 color = Color.Blue,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold
 )

 Spacer(modifier = Modifier.width(10.dp))

 Button({},
 colors = ButtonDefaults.buttonColors(containerColor = Color.Black),
 modifier = Modifier.padding()){
 Icon(imageVector = Icons.Default.Add, contentDescription = "Add",
 tint = Color.White)
 Text(text = "Join Now", color = Color.White)
 }
 
 }
 Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(10.dp))
 }
 }

 }



}

why is only one text showing in box even though three text are placed in row?
</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Great question! The reason only one `Text` is showing up in the `Row` inside your `Card` is because of how you're using the `Modifier.fillMaxWidth()` for each `Column`.

**Problem:** 
In your `Row`, you have three `Column`s, each with the modifier `.fillMaxWidth()`. This tells each `Column` to try to take up the entire width of the parent Row. But in a Row, siblings are laid out side by side, and if each wants the whole width, only the first actually gets to use it—the others get squished, likely to 0 size, so their content doesn't render.

**Solution:** 
Instead, use `.weight(1f)` for each `Column` so that they distribute the available horizontal space equally among them. Remove the `.fillMaxWidth()` from the `Column`s inside the `Row`.

**How to fix:**

Replace this in your row:
```kotlin
Column(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
 // ...
) { ... }
```
with:
```kotlin
Column(
 modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
 // ...
) { ... }
```
Do this for all three `Column`s within the target `Row`.

---

**Result:** 
Now each column will have equal width, and all your `Text`s will be visible side-by-side in the Row as intended!

Would you like me to make this change directly in your code?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You've made great progress! The adjustment to use `weight(1f)` for each `Column` is correct. Now, to ensure all the content in the `Card` (including the three columns) is perfectly centered vertically as well as horizontally inside the `Card`, you just need a small tweak for the `Row` that's inside the `Card`.

**What's happening now:**
- Your `Row` inside the `Card` has `verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically`, so the internal content is centered vertically within the `Row`.
- But if the `Row` isn't set to fill the height of the `Card` (or center within the `Card`), there will be unused space above/below if the content is not tall enough — so visually, the content might still appear "stuck" to the top.

**Solution:**
Add `.fillMaxHeight()` to that `Row` inside the `Card`, and ensure the internal Columns are actually centering their content (which you already do). Optionally, you can add some vertical padding to the `Row` to make it feel more visually balanced.

---

### How to update

**Replace this part:**
```kotlin
Row(
 horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
 verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
){
 // ...
}
```

**With this:**
```kotlin
Row(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxHeight()
 .padding(vertical = 8.dp), // Optional: adjust as you like
 horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
 verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
) {
 // ...
}
```

---

**Result:** 
This change will ensure your three columns (and thus, all `Text` in them) are perfectly centered both vertically and horizontally inside the `Card`, making it look professional and balanced.

Would you like me to go ahead and apply this change?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You’re correct—when you add a `HorizontalDivider` inside a `Row` or `Card`, by default, it appears at the top of its container because composables in a column or card stack from top to bottom if not controlled otherwise.

**To position a `HorizontalDivider` in the vertical center,** you should:
1. Place it inside a `Column`, not a `Row`, and control its vertical positioning with spacers or by putting it between the elements you want to separate.
2. If you want it to appear “centered” within the card (for instance, below the `Row` or between elements), you place it after the first part of content and before the next part within a `Column`.
3. To vertically align the divider within the card that is otherwise using a `Row`, you can wrap the whole card content in a `Column` and insert the `HorizontalDivider` at the desired position.

---

## Example: Horizontal Divider Centered Within Card

Here’s a pattern that centers the divider within a card:

```kotlin
Card(
 // ... card args ...
) {
 Column(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
 verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
 horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
 ) {
 Row(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .weight(1f), // take up available space
 horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
 verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
 ) {
 // ... your three columns here ...
 }

 // Insert the divider here, below the row
 HorizontalDivider(
 modifier = Modifier.padding(horizontal = 10.dp),
 thickness = 7.dp,
 color = Color.White
 )

 // You can add content below the divider if you want
 // ...
 }
}
```

**Key Point:** 
- `HorizontalDivider` should not be placed directly in a `Row` if you want vertical centering in the card—you should structure your layout with a `Column` as the main container inside the card and control vertical placement relative to other content.

---

**Summary:** 
- Place the divider within a `Column` at the desired point relative to your content.
- In a `Row`, vertical items can only be centered horizontally; for stacking vertical elements and placing a divider between, use a `Column`.

Would you like help refactoring your card’s contents into a column so you can control the divider’s position? Or do you want the divider between certain elements? If you clarify the exact layout you want, I can provide the precise code!"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Great! If you want the `HorizontalDivider` to appear “outside the box” (i.e., outside and below the `Card`), you should place it after the `Card` in the parent `Column`.

Here’s how to do it in your setup:

**How to place the divider outside (below) the Card:**

Find the place in your composable where you have your `Card`:
```kotlin
Card(
 modifier = Modifier
 .size(width = 350.dp, height = 100.dp)
 .align(Alignment.CenterHorizontally)
 .background(Color.Black),
 // ... rest of your Card code ...
) {
 // ... Card content ...
}
```

**Immediately after** the closing brace of your `Card`, add your `HorizontalDivider`:
```kotlin
Card(
 // ...
) {
 // ...
}

// Place divider below the Card, but still inside the parent Column:
HorizontalDivider(
 modifier = Modifier
 .padding(horizontal = 10.dp),
 thickness = 7.dp,
 color = Color.White
)
```

**Where to put it?** 
Put it right after the `Card` in the same parent `Column` where the `Card` sits, like so:

```kotlin
Column(
 // ... Column modifiers ...
) {
 Row(
 // ... Row modifiers and contents ...
 )
 Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(20.dp))
 Card(
 // ... Card
 ) {
 // ... Card contents ...
 }
 // Put your divider here:
 HorizontalDivider(
 modifier = Modifier.padding(horizontal = 10.dp),
 thickness = 7.dp,
 color = Color.White
 )
}
```

**Result:** 
Your divider will show up immediately **below** the card, and “outside” of it.

You want the divider immediately after the entire black section—including the header (with title and icons) and the statistics card—so the divider comes after everything within the black background, not in the middle.

**What you need:** 
Place the `HorizontalDivider` right after the closing brace of the whole black box `Column`, but inside the top-level `Box` (not inside the `Column`).

---

## How to do it:

Here’s the structure you want:

```kotlin
Box(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxSize()
 .background(Color.White),
 contentAlignment = Alignment.TopCenter
) {
 // This Column is your full black banner area:
 Column(
 verticalArrangement = Arrangement.Center,
 horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .height(250.dp)
 .background(Color.Black)
 ) {
 // ...header row, card, etc...
 } // <--- End of the black box Column

 // Place the divider after the black column, but still inside Box:
 // Add this after the Column, in the Box's body:

 HorizontalDivider(
 modifier = Modifier
 .align(Alignment.TopCenter) // Aligns with the top center of the Box
 .padding(top = 250.dp, start = 10.dp, end = 10.dp), // Move divider below the black box (250.dp high)
 thickness = 3.dp,
 color = Color.Black
 )
}
```

### The reasoning:
- The `.padding(top = 250.dp)` moves the divider exactly below the 250.dp black section.
- The `HorizontalDivider` uses `start` and `end` padding for side spacing, and thickness/colors as you wish.
- `align(Alignment.TopCenter)` ensures it's horizontally centered in the Box.

---

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The issue here is how Compose layouts work for overlapping components in a `Box`. In your current code, both the `Column` (the black background "box") and the `HorizontalDivider` are direct children of the same parent `Box`. A `Spacer` inside the `Box` itself will not move the divider because `Box` stacks children on top of each other based on their order and alignment, rather than laying them out sequentially like a `Column`.

**Why your Spacer is not working:** 
Composables like `Spacer` create visual space in `Column`s or `Row`s where elements are laid out in sequence. But in a `Box`, children are layered (overlapping) based on their alignment and positioning.

**How you should space it out:** 
You should align and position the `HorizontalDivider` to appear exactly after the black box by using the `Modifier.align()` and a proper amount of `padding(top = ...)`.

Since your black `Column` has a fixed height (`height(250.dp)`), and you want the divider immediately below it, simply set the divider's `Modifier` to:
- `align(Alignment.TopCenter)`
- `padding(top = 250.dp)`

No additional `Spacer` is necessary in a `Box`, and extra `Spacer` will not create visual gaps in this context.

---

## The Correct Way (in your Box):

```kotlin
Box(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxSize()
 .background(Color.White),
 contentAlignment = Alignment.TopCenter
) {
 Column(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .height(250.dp)
 .background(Color.Black),
 // ... other modifiers ...
 ) {
 // ... content ...
 }

 // Place the divider exactly below the Column using padding
 HorizontalDivider(
 modifier = Modifier
 .align(Alignment.TopCenter) // Ensures divider stays at the top center
 .padding(top = 250.dp, start = 10.dp, end = 10.dp), // moves divider below black box
 thickness = 3.dp,
 color = Color.Black
 )
}
```

**Summary:** 
- In a `Box`, use `.align()` and `.padding(top = ...)` on the `HorizontalDivider` to place it visually after the full black box.
- `Spacer` only works sequentially inside `Column`/`Row`, not in a `Box` used for stacking.

Let me know if you want this change made directly in your file!"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is a classic Composable layout question!

### What’s happening:
- When you put your “Upcoming Events” `Text` (and its parent `Column`) inside the big black box `Column`, it inherits the black background and the height constraint.
- That’s why it appears **inside** the box/black area.

### To achieve what you want:
- Keep the “Upcoming Events” section outside the large black background `Column`, but still inside the top-level `Box`.
- You may want to ensure there’s spacing or a divider between the black box and the "Upcoming Events" title.

---

### How to do it:

**Keep the structure like this:**

```kotlin
Box(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize().background(Color.White),
 contentAlignment = Alignment.TopCenter
) {
 // The BLACK section (Header, stats card)
 Column(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .height(250.dp)
 .background(Color.Black)
 ) {
 // ...header and stats card...
 }

 // Everything below appears visually ON TOP of the Box, so they'll overlap unless spaced down!
 Column(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .padding(top = 250.dp) // <-- moves "Upcoming Events" below the black box
 ) {
 // Divider for separation (optional)
 HorizontalDivider(
 modifier = Modifier.padding(horizontal = 10.dp),
 thickness = 3.dp,
 color = Color.Black
 )
 // Your event section
 Text(
 "Upcoming Events",
 color = Color.Black,
 fontSize = 20.sp,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
 modifier = Modifier.padding(start = 16.dp, top = 16.dp)
 )
 // ... more content ...
 }
}
```

**Key Points:**
- `.padding(top = 250.dp)` on your outer (second) `Column` ensures it is visually below the black area.
- You can add a `HorizontalDivider` at the top of this new column for separation if you wish.
- Do not put the “Upcoming Events” `Column` inside the black `Column`.

---

### The Goal
- Show the image at the top (with `AsyncImage`).
- Overlay the date text at the top-right **over** the image.

### How to achieve this:
You need to wrap the image and the date text inside a `Box`. This allows you to stack the date `Text` on top of the image and position it in the top right.

---

## Example Implementation

Replace this part inside your `Card`:
```kotlin
AsyncImage(
 modifier = Modifier.height(300.dp),
 model = singleEvent.img,
 contentDescription = singleEvent.title
)
// ... rest of your code ...
```
**With:**
```kotlin
Box(
 modifier = Modifier.height(300.dp)
) {
 AsyncImage(
 modifier = Modifier.matchParentSize(),
 model = singleEvent.img,
 contentDescription = singleEvent.title
 )
 Text(
 text = singleEvent.date,
 color = Color.White, // Or any contrasting color
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
 modifier = Modifier
 .align(Alignment.TopEnd)
 .padding(12.dp)
 // Optional decoration to make it visible over any image:
 //.background(Color.Black.copy(alpha = 0.6f), shape = RoundedCornerShape(8.dp))
 //.padding(horizontal = 8.dp, vertical = 4.dp)
 )
}
```

- This will overlay the event date at the top-right of the image.
- Adjust `padding` as needed for your visual preference.
- Optionally, use a background behind the date for better visibility.

**Do not put the date after the card**—placing it "after the card" means it will be below the entire card, not overlaying the image.

---

Here's what you'll need:
- A Dialog with:
 - Title ("Create New Event")
 - Text fields for Event Name, Date, Time, Description (with styled hints)
 - Character count for the description
 - Cancel and Create Event buttons

**Let's break it down.**

---

## 1. State Variables (to store form input)

Add these to the composable where you show the dialog (e.g., inside `HomeScreen`):

```kotlin
// Add these at the top of HomeScreen (inside the @Composable function):
var eventName by remember { mutableStateOf("") }
var eventDate by remember { mutableStateOf("") }
var eventTime by remember { mutableStateOf("") }
var eventDescription by remember { mutableStateOf("") }
// You might consider image picker, but the mockup doesn't show it yet
```

## 2. Dialog Layout

Here is a Compose implementation for the dialog UI:

```kotlin
if (showAddEventButton){
 Dialog(onDismissRequest = { showAddEventButton = false }) {
 Surface(
 shape = RoundedCornerShape(16.dp),
 color = Color.White,
 modifier = Modifier
 .width(340.dp)
 .padding(16.dp)
 ) {
 Column(modifier = Modifier.padding(24.dp)) {
 Text(
 text = "Create New Event",
 fontSize = 20.sp,
 fontWeight = FontWeight.Bold,
 color = Color.Black
 )
 Spacer(Modifier.height(16.dp))
 // Event Name
 OutlinedTextField(
 value = eventName,
 onValueChange = { eventName = it },
 label = { Text("Event Name") },
 placeholder = { Text("Enter event name") },
 singleLine = true,
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()
 )
 Spacer(Modifier.height(10.dp))
 // Date & Time Row
 Row(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth()) {
 OutlinedTextField(
 value = eventDate,
 onValueChange = { eventDate = it },
 label = { Text("Date") },
 placeholder = { Text("dd-mm-yyyy") },
 singleLine = true,
 modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)
 )
 Spacer(Modifier.width(10.dp))
 OutlinedTextField(
 value = eventTime,
 onValueChange = { eventTime = it },
 label = { Text("Time") },
 placeholder = { Text("--:--") },
 singleLine = true,
 modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)
 )
 }
 Spacer(Modifier.height(10.dp))
 // Description
 OutlinedTextField(
 value = eventDescription,
 onValueChange = {
 if (it.length <= 500) eventDescription = it
 },
 label = { Text("Description") },
 placeholder = { Text("Describe your event...") },
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .height(100.dp),
 maxLines = 5
 )
 Text(
 text = "${eventDescription.length}/500",
 modifier = Modifier.align(Alignment.End),
 fontSize = 12.sp,
 color = Color.Gray
 )
 Spacer(Modifier.height(20.dp))
 Row(
 Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
 horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceBetween
 ) {
 OutlinedButton(
 onClick = { showAddEventButton = false },
 modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)
 ) {
 Text("Cancel")
 }
 Spacer(Modifier.width(16.dp))
 Button(
 onClick = {
 // Create your SingleEvent and add to your events list here
 showAddEventButton = false
 },
 modifier = Modifier.weight(1f),
 enabled = eventName.isNotBlank() && eventDate.isNotBlank() && eventTime.isNotBlank()
 ) {
 Text("Create Event")
 }
 }
 }
 }
 }
}
```

---

## 3. Data Handling

```kotlin

 img = Uri.EMPTY, // Or some default Uri
 date = eventDate,
 title = eventName,
 time = eventTime,
 description = eventDescription,
 location = "" // You may add another field for location if needed
)
// Add newEvent to your list, then dismiss dialog.
```

---

## 4. Required Imports
Be sure the following Compose Material 3 (or 2) imports are present if you’re using these components:
```kotlin
import androidx.compose.material3.*
import androidx.compose.runtime.*
import androidx.compose.ui.unit.*
import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.*
import androidx.compose.ui.Alignment
// And others as needed
```

---

## 5. **Result**
This dialog will match the design in your screenshot, and its data maps to your `SingleEvent` model.
